item.content:encoded:
Is Hanoi worth visiting? Many people ask us this question when preparing their trip to Vietnam. For us, without a doubt Hanoi is worth visiting. We fell in love with this city as soon as we arrived. The traffic is the first thing that  will caught your attention, as it really is madness! The quarters are beautiful and you can see Hanoi’s history through its buildings. People sitting outside and sipping coffee all day long. And no, we are not talking about any coffee…did you know that only the coffee already makes Hanoi worth visiting? It’s amazing!

How long should I stay?

You can tick off the main attractions in 2 nights, but if you add another night you won’t regret it. Also, Hanoi is the perfect base to do trips to Sapa, Ha Long Bay, Ha Giang or Ninh Binh. Check our map with a 3 week itinerary to see how to best move around.

How expensive is Hanoi?

Another thing that makes Hanoi worth visiting is its terrific value. Some examples:

  • You can find budget accommodation for under 10$ the night, and for 15-20$ you'll get very comfortable and cool places
  • Amazing Vietnamese coffee is under a dollar
  • Food ranges from 2$ to 4$ for local food and a bit more expensive for western dishes
  • Taxis are crazy cheap if you use GRAB. A 5 minutes ride is about a dollar

How to get from the airport

I know there are buses, but seriously, make yourself a favour and just get a GRAB. It is cheaper than the bus and more comfortable. We paid 10$ from the airport to the city centre.

Where to stay

Budget option: Old Quarter View Hanoi Hostel

Located in the heart of the Old Quarter, it is the perfect hostel for backpackers. Comfort and value at the same time, it has options for under 10$ a night, breakfast included.

Comfort option: Hanoi La Selva

Great facilities and lovely staff at a very reasonable price. Gorgeous rooms and located in the Old Quarter, next to the Hoan Kiem lake.

 

Ok, what should I see?

-Hoan Kiem Lake and Ngog Son

Hoan Kiem lake is one of the icons of Hanoi. Have a walk around and visit Ngog Son, a temple located on a small island in the middle of the lake. Once you’re done, please visit the “Note Coffee“, just in the corner. It has a great variety of ice creams and coffee, and although it is a bit expensive for Vietnamese standards, it is well worth it.

-Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum

A very interesting visit from a cultural and anthropological point of view. You will be sharing your visit with hundreds of North-Vietnamese, who daily show their respect for their leader. The ticket entrance also includes a visit to Ho Chi Minh’s old residence, gardens and even cars.

TIP: Go early in the morning. Otherwise, you WILL queue for hours.

-Hoa Lo Prison

It was a prison used by the French colonists for Vietnamese political prisoners. Later, North Vietnam used it for U.S prisoners of war, such as the United States Senator John McCain. During this time, the prison got a new nickname: the Hanoi Hilton. We found a bit too much propaganda in the visit, but it is definitely a great place to learn more about Vietnam’s history.

-Old Quarter

 

The Old Quarter is the heart of Hanoi. All the markets are here, along with restaurants, old houses, museums, souvenirs shops, etc. Make sure you spend some quality time here but be aware that it can sometimes be a bit overwhelming. During the weekend, the main streets are closed at night and there is a night market.

TIP: If you like homemade beer, visit Ta Hien Street, also known as beer street. One beer just 0.3$! YES, you read correctly!

-Train street

One of the most popular attractions of Hanoi. Two trains run daily along Le Duan and Kham Tien streets. The street is very narrow and people actually live there, so don’t be surprised if you find people sitting on a chair having their lunch on the railway or chickens running around.

TIP: The trains passes at 3.30pm and 7.30pm. Make sure you arrive a bit earlier to grab a nice spot!

 

Other places in Hanoi worth visiting…

-Wander around the French Quarter and enjoy the architecture

-Don Xuan Market. You can find pretty much anything here. Prices are good but be aware that sellers aren’t particularly nice, we discovered this the hard way!

-Museum of Anthropology. Especially interesting if you want to know about the different tribes that live in the North of Vietnam. Did you know there are at least 54 ethnic minorities, each with its own language, lifestyle, and cultural heritage?

-Water puppet theater

-Opera house

Ok ok, too much sightseeing…what about trying something different?

One of our best experiences was doing a food tour of https://www.hanoifreewalkingtours.com/. Brian, a university student from Hanoi, helped us to discover Vietnamese cuisine. We visited 5 different restaurants, and some of them were places that you probably wouldn’t visit on your own. The food was in general delicious and it was very nice to get to know someone local.

The tour is FREE. You obviously pay for all the food (less than 15$), including your guide’s. A tip is also appreciated. You won’t regret doing the tour and it will make your trip to Vietnam easier as you will know what to order from this point.

Sooo, what are you waiting for to visit Hanoi?

3 Week Vietnam Itinerary

Make sure you check our complete guide with all the tips on how to organise your time in this amazing country! Where to stay, how to travel around and what not to miss!

The post Is Hanoi worth visiting? The ultimate 3 days guide appeared first on It feels good to be lost.

item.title: 3 week Vietnam itinerary from north to south
item.dc:creator: rafag
item.description:

item.content:encoded:
Planning a trip to Vietnam is definitely exciting. However, Vietnam is quite a big country and is hard to gauge how long you should spend in each place to make the most of it. The good news for you is that we’re here to help you organise your 3 week Vietnam itinerary. With our guide, you’ll go from north to south, but you could start in the south if it works best for you, it’s not a problem at all. Worth mentioning, we take our time when visiting places, as we don’t like visiting places just to put a tick on it.

But before we start…

HOW MUCH MONEY DO I NEED?

The currency is the Vietnamese Dong. You’ll get about 23,000 Dongs for a Dollar.

1 USD = 23,000 VND 

Vietnam is a very cheap country, but it can also become expensive if you aren’t careful. Budget accommodations range between 15$ to 30$ per night, while food ranges between 2$ and 7$. If you really take good care of your money, you can allocate a 30$ budget per day. A 50$ per day budget will make a great holiday though.

  • 15$ - 30$ per night
  • 2$ - 7$
  • ~1$
  • TOTAL: 30$ per day

VISA

A very important thing to double check. Vietnam is more restrictive than other countries in South East Asia. Many nationalities get a 15 days visa on arrival, but others will need to apply for it before landing in Vietnam.

If for example, you want to follow our 3 week Vietnam itinerary, you’ll need to apply for a visa. You can do it online, taking 3 days and costing you 30$. If you didn’t do your homework and you’re short on time, there are some companies who will make a visa for you in even 15 minutes, but prepare the wallet…

3 WEEK VIETNAM ITINERARY

Hanoi- 3 nights

Hanoi is the first stop of our 3 week Vietnam itinerary. You could easily see everything in 2 days but we think you will appreciate Hanoi more if you take it easy.

The capital of Vietnam is one of the most lively cities we’ve ever been to. People just pass their day sitting on the street and sipping (amazing!) coffee. You will see the worst traffic you’ve ever witnessed, but don’t let that put you off. Hanoi is a beautiful city full of lovely quarters, things to do and new food to experience.

For a detailed guide to Hanoi – check our post 

Must do things…

– Roam around Hoan Kiem lake. Visit Ngoc Son, a small temple situated in the middle of the lake.
– Wander around the Old and French Quarters.
– Visit the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. It’s incredible how much respect North-Vietnamese’s have for their old leader.
– Visit Hoa Lo prison, colloquially known as “Hanoi Hilton”.
– See the train passing on the  famous “Train street”
– We did a free food tour of https://www.hanoifreewalkingtours.com/ and it was amazing. The guides are students and they will take you to places that you would not go on your own. Great way to get you started with Vietnamese’s food.

Other things you could do…

– Don Xuan Market. You can find pretty much anything here.
– Museum of Anthropology, especially interesting if you’re into finding out about the different tribes that live in the North of Vietnam.
– Water puppet theatre.
– Opera house.

TIP: If you get to Hanoi via plane, don’t take a creepy taxi to go to the city centre. Download GRAB. It cost us 10$ to go to the city centre, 3 times cheaper than the price the taxi drivers offer.

Where to stay

Budget option: Old Quarter View Hanoi Hostel

Located in the heart of the Old Quarter, it is the perfect hostel for backpackers. Comfort and value at the same time, it has options for under 10$ a night, breakfast included.

Comfort option: Hanoi La Selva

Great facilities and lovely staff at a very reasonable price. Gorgeous rooms and located in the Old Quarter, next to Hoan Kiem lake.

Sapa -2 nights-

The landscapes of the very north of Vietnam are a must see and you shouldn’t miss them. The easiest place to visit is Sapa, this comes at a cost though. We’ve heard Sapa can be very touristic and a bit fake. However, if you’re clever and book the right trekking, your experience will have nothing to do with that.

TIP: You can avoid paying one night of accommodation by taking this very comfortable night bus.

Our Trekking

We booked a trekking called “Off the beaten track” with Sapa O’Chau and it was one of the best experiences we’ve had when travelling. More about this here and here.

Where to stay

Budget option: Sapa O’Chau

Sapa O’Chau is also a humble hotel. You can stay here the night before/after your trekking. The rooms are clean and quite cheap, so it has good value.

Comfort option: Eco Palms House Retreat

For those looking for a eco retreat. Bungalows in the middle of rice-fields with amazing views to the mountain. You can also appreciate the views while sipping wine in a bath tub.

Ha Long Bay – 1 or 2 nights-

Our 3 week Vietnam itinerary would not be complete without a visit to Ha Long Bay, one of the highlights of every visitor to Vietnam. A boat cruise will take you around the Bay for 1 or 2 nights, depending on how long you choose to stay. We’re budget travellers, so we chose 1 night. Most of the companies will include transportation from Hanoi to Ha Long Bay in the price.

We’ve written this post about how to choose between Sapa or Ha Long Bay in case you’re short on time or budget.

TIP: Boats usually spend the night in Ha Long Bay, meaning you end up sharing the night with hundreds of boats. Some cruises take a slightly different route, sleeping in Bai Tu Long Bay. This will make your experience MUCH BETTER. Our sunset was unforgettable.

Our choice

We took the package called “Off the beaten track” offered by Indochina Junk. With this option, you’ll spend the night in Bai Tu Long Bay. More about our experience here.

Ninh Binh -2 nights-

We got to Ninh Binh via train from Hanoi. We had a great time biking around Tam Coc, although we were a bit unlucky as we had heavy rain for one day, meaning we couldn’t make it to the national park. Still, we had an amazing time in this beautiful countryside area.

Must do things…

– Tam Coc lake tour. One hour stroll in a small boat. The landscape is very similar to Ha Long Bay but it is still worth it.
– Bich Dong Pagoda
– Bird Valley
– Mua cave. The cave is the least important thing, make sure you hike the mountain to get the perfect views!

Other things you could do…

– Cuc Phong National Park.

TIP: Rent a bike (most hostels provide very cheap bikes) and cycle everywhere. The roads are very safe and the views deserve to be appreciated. You won’t get the same experience using Tuk Tuks or motorbikes.

Where to stay

Budget option: Tam Coc Dream Hostel

Awesome value. The location is just perfect, very close to many restaurants and attractions. The woman who runs it is great and the family, in general, will do everything they can to make you happy. They also offer cheap bikes rental and will help you booking buses to your next destination.

Comfort option: Tam Coc Horizon Bungalow

Outstanding bungalows surrounded by amazing landscapes. The atmosphere and the staff are both simply incredible. Probably the best place to stay in Ninh Binh.

Hue -1 night-

We got to Hue by night bus from Ninh Binh. Be aware the bus wasn’t particularly safe, nothing do with the one we took to go to Sapa.

Hue is the city of the Citadel. While the Citadel is impressive and very interesting from a historical point of view, if we had to cut down one day from our itinerary it would be Hue. Still, we had a nice day and enjoyed the city. During the night there is a nice market by the river and many nice options for dinner.

Must do things…

– Hue Citadel and Forbidden City
– Walk stroll next to the river. There are many markets and restaurants

Where to stay

Budget option: Bonjour Hostel

Well located, very clean and offering rooms under 10$ the night depending on the dates. Delicious breakfast included! Just tremendous value.

Comfort option: The Scarlett Boutique Hotel

Very affordable luxury rooms (about 50$ the night). One of the most visited and prestigious hotels in Hue, you can’t go wrong with it.

Hoi An -6 nights-

Continuing our 3 week Vietnam itinerary, we’ll get to Hoi An. To get to this gem town, we strongly recommend the train if you come from Hue. It goes next to the Hai Van pass, a 21 km mountain pass with beautiful views to the sea.

Hoi An is no doubt our favourite city of Vietnam. Beach, rice fields and a beautiful old town make the city of the lanterns one of the most unique places we’ve ever visited. We have to admit we loved it so much we ended up staying for 10 days, 4 days more than we had planned.

Must do things…

– An Bang beach. Relaxing beach with very good and tasty restaurants. Also, you can do parasailing for 30$ 2 persons. We did it and was AMAZING.
– The old town at night. Have a stroll at the old town in the night, when all the lanterns are on. Simply beautiful.

– No better city to buy souvenirs. We bought a few too many lanterns (but we don’t regret it!).
– Ride a motorbike around Hoi An. We’ll never forget the joy of riding the motorbike from the city centre to the beach, passing next to the rice fields.

Other things you could do…

– Ancient town tour. Old houses, museums, Japanese covered bridge, etc.
– Marble Mountains, halfway between Da Nang and Hoi An.

TIP: Motorbike is a must in Hoi An. The roads are good and traffic is more “western” than in other places of the country. Another plus: you won’t have to deal with tuk-tuk or taxi drivers.

Where to stay

Budget option: Melody Boutique Villa Hoi An

Modern construction, clean, fresh and very comfortable. The staff is amazing and will help you with anything you need. Bicycles and scooters available for rental at very affordable prices. Amazing value (rooms under 15$ the night).

Comfort option: Little Town Villa

Luxury but affordable villa in the old town. Spacious rooms and tasteful decoration. The breakfast is great, with both local and international options. Swimming pool to cool down after a long walk around the old town.

Da Lat -3 nights-

Following our 3 week Vietnam itinerary, it is now time for some adventure! Da Lat is known for its hills, forests and waterfalls and it’s a place you can’t miss.

Must do things…

– Rapelling waterfalls
– Visiting Pongour Falls

Where to stay

Budget option: Gia Pham Hotel

Very comfortable private room for under 8$ per night. Value doesn’t get better than this. Extremely helpful staff and very good location.

Comfort option: Doc May Boutique Villa

A little boutique place to an exceptional price. The villa location is great and you can walk or cycle pretty much anywhere, including the night market.

Ho Chi Minh -2 nights-

The last stop of our 3 week Vietnam itinerary is Ho Chi Minh, also known as Saigon. We stayed 2 nights but 1 night-2 days works well too.

The capital of what it was “South Vietnam”, it is as vibrant or more than Hanoi. Also, it is a great city to learn more about Vietnam’s war with the Americans.

Must do things…

– Walk around District 1.
– Memorial war museum.
– Cu Chi Tunnels.

TIP: If you want to visit the real Cu Chi Tunnels, check out this post to visit them on your own.

Where to stay

Budget option: Couchsurfing with Saigon English Adventures

We did Couchsurfing with Saigon English Adventures English academy and absolutely loved it. You get to stay for free in exchange of being part of some English classes, where you will meet amazing locals. More about our experience here. Honestly, this was the nicest experience we’ve had in Vietnam.

Comfort option: Boholand Hostel

We didn’t stay here as we were Couchsurfing, but a couple of Canadian friends that we met did. Peaceful and well located in District one, close to all the main attractions. The woman who runs it apparently is very nice and the breakfast is great. Room prices are under 20$ per night

Other places you could visit

-Ha Giang. Not including this one in our 3 week Vietnam itinerary really hurt. This province is in the North of Vietnam, next to the Chinese border. This is a less touristic alternative to Sapa. Unfortunately, you should do it only if you have around 4-5 days, as it is very remote and takes some time to get there.

– Nha Trang. A coastal resort city in Southern Vietnam known for its beaches. From what we read, it is very touristic in a bad way (dirty beaches, party, etc).

– Phong Nha national park. Mountains, forest, rivers and caves. Good trekking and good adventures from our friends’ experiences!

Sharing is caring!

Hope you enjoyed our 3 week Vietnam itinerary as much as we did visiting this wonderful country. Feel free to drop us a comment and share it with friends!

The post 3 week Vietnam itinerary from north to south appeared first on It feels good to be lost.

item.title: Cheap day in Singapore: must-see that won’t ruin your pocket
item.dc:creator: rafag
item.description:
Singapore is an amazing city but compared to rest of SE Asia it is quite expensive. Lucky for you, we have a solution! In this guide, we’ll show how you to spend a cheap day in Singapore and still enjoy the main attractions the city has to offer, plus you’ll do it in a very […]

The post Cheap day in Singapore: must-see that won’t ruin your pocket appeared first on It feels good to be lost.
item.content:encoded:
Singapore is an amazing city but compared to rest of SE Asia it is quite expensive. Lucky for you, we have a solution! In this guide, we’ll show how you to spend a cheap day in Singapore and still enjoy the main attractions the city has to offer, plus you’ll do it in a very cool way! And no, we are not talking of boring two-floor touristic bus!

Where to stay?

Backpacker option: The InnCrowd Hostel

 This backpacker hostel is located in Little India. The hostel has everything you need to have a comfortable stay: helpful 24 hours reception, kitchen, breakfast included and comfortable beds. Plus, they offer many free tours, which will be key for our perfect cheap day in Singapore. We’ll talk about the Scooter tour in particular later in this article. 
 

Comfortable option: Pan Pacific Singapore

Fantastic views, all amenities you could ask for, great location, great staff…if you’re after a comfortable stay you won’t be disappointed.
 
 

5 stops guide to the perfect cheap day in Singapore

1. Little India

We started our day here since The InnCrowd hostel is in Little India. Just roam around, get lost and discover Little India’s street art, small shops with beauty products and colourful sarees (traditional Indian outfit). The smell of fresh flower garlands, mixed with incense and spices will make you feel like you have travelled to India. 

You can finish in Tekka market in case you want to taste some authentic Indian food (it is super cheap and delicious). We can recommend Chicken Tikka Masala with Naan (mild spicy chicken with flat bread).

2. Chinatown

Our next stop is Chinatown, you can either walk or get by the MRT. Have a stroll and visit the  shops around the area. You can pretty much buy any gift you want for very small money. There is really really nice stuff, such as handmade ceramics, lanterns, fortune knots or lucky golden cats. It is also a good place to have lunch since there is a very long food court with hundreds food stalls.

Weirdly enough, there is also a beautiful Hindu temple worth a visit. It is free of charge, so make sure you don’t miss it!

3. Kampong Glam

A must-see on our cheap day in Singapore itinerary is the Kampong Glam, the Arab quarter, walking distance from Little India. Get lost in the narrow streets and make your way to the Sultan Mosque (Masjid Sultan). It opens from 10 to 12 and 14 to 16 so make sure you go in these windows if you want to visit it. There are many places to have an Arab meal but keep in mind they can be quite pricey. TIP: if you want to eat cheap- eat like a local. 

TIP: Make sure to check out the Haji Lane – vibrant street art, many boutique shops with crafts and original souvenirs, independent coffee shops and small restaurants.

4. The Cloud Forest at Gardens by the Bay

Another cool place to visit is the famous Cloud Forest. It isn’t free, but we definitely recommend it. The hostel provides a discount for the entry so ask at the reception for one – this way you can make the most of your cheap day in Singapore. 

The view at the entrance is spectacular- 35 meters high waterfalls surrounded by the glass dome. The best time to go is afternoon – it gets too hot to be outside so you will really appreciate the refreshing and moist climate when you roam around the forest. The biodiversity there is amazing.

Regular price: 28$, after hostel discount: 26$. The ticket includes entrance to the Flower Dome

Opening hours: 9.00am – 9.00pm daily (Last admission: 8.00pm)

5. Afternoon SCOOTER TOUR – Let the fun begin!

Now, the highlight of your cheap day in Singapore.

The InnCrowd hostel offers an amazing free-tour where you can get to know Singapore in a Scooter. Regardless of you staying in the hostel or not, I think it should be alright to join the free-tour as it is an external person who organise it. Make sure you pass by reception and save your slot asap!

The guide will give you your 2 wheels scooter. We had ZERO experience with this, but don’t worry, after 2 minutes you’ll be having fun like 5 years old. The guide takes you around the whole city, making several stops for shows and attractions. You will pass by the Kampong Glam, skyscrapers in the downtown and head to Marina Bay. We won’t spoil too many details, find out for yourself! 

The highlight of the free tour is grabbing a local dinner in a market to later eat it in Marina Bay in front of the light&water show. Then, you will ride to Gardens by the Bay to see another show- all trees will illuminate with colours. Just lay on the ground and enjoy the show!

You will get back to The InnCrowd hostel 4 hours later. Heads up, you will sleep like a baby that night!

If you have extra time or want to go off the beaten track here are a few cool ideas to extend your cheap day in Singapore:

– Lovely Chinese houses, perfect pic for your Instagram feed. Take the underground to Paya Lebar or Eunos station

– Check out the colourful building of the Old Hill Street Police Station. You will find it on your way to Chinatown (it looks like a rainbow) 

Not so keen on scooter? Here are other options to move around city during your cheap day in Singapore:

  • Bike - there are several mobile apps offering cheap bike rides- we used this one: Ofo (click here to download). The best thing is that you just grab the bike from the street and leave it whenever you wish (no docking stations). There is plenty of them and all the bikes are new and easy to ride. With the code: YvBwDl you will get the first week FREE
  • MRT - it is quick and cheap, unlike other things in Singapore. Just get a top up card at the station and every time you ride underground, it will be deducted from your balance
  • Grab - the Uber of Asia
  • or just walk - most of the landmarks are in walking distance

Hope you liked our guide to "cheap day in Singapore", if so share it!

Enjoy the scooter ride and let us know how was it!

The post Cheap day in Singapore: must-see that won’t ruin your pocket appeared first on It feels good to be lost.

item.content:encoded:
30
bad things about long-term travelling

Travelling is amazing, it really is. But before you are ready to quit your job, grab your other half and hop onto a plane, these are our 30 bad things about long-term travelling that no one told you about

  • 1. Although you may think you are better than that- you WILL miss a flight, it is just a matter of time.
  • 2. You will get sick and freak out it is malaria or dengue fever...but it is just a food poisoning. And probably with the meal that you expect the least (hamburger with chips, yep!).
  • 3. It's a full-time job and you will spend days organizing itineraries (AND YOUR GIRLFRIEND PROBABLY DOESN'T HELP YOU). You will even consider becoming a travel agen.
  • 4. At some point you will have problems with visas, either entering or leaving a country. We had to spend 24 hours in HK airport awaiting Iga's urgent visa to be issued. BTW, this is how we missed our first flight
  • 5. The transition from a 2 bedroom flat to one backpack is liberating but tricky. You will most surely pack way too much stuff and your backpack weights more than a baby elephant. One by one, you will throw away that "extra thing in case we need it" and regret taking it with you in the first place.
  • 6. You will get homesick, everyone does. "I want to sleep in, wear pyjamas all day long watching Netflix on my sofa" type of thing
  • 7. You will understand long-term travelling is exhausting. Really, it is.
  • 8. You will miss your best friends as hell, and the time difference does not help.
  • 9. HOW MANY PLUG ADAPTERS EXIST?
  • 10. There will be days when you'll miss your comfort food so much that you will end up paying double for the "Italian" pizza that tastes like a chewing gum (pizza in Asia sucks)
  • 11. Soon enough you will realize that most of your friends don't really care about your "one in a lifetime adventure". They are busy living their lives and will hate you for all the cool pics you post on IG. They will divide into "that is so amazing guys, I want to travel like you!" and those who jealously think that you have rich parents or secretly won a lottery.
FYI: if you want to find out how we managed to visit SE Asia on a limited budget- check this post
  • 12. There will be days when you will join that second group in though self-criticism and will question your life choices. "It is time to grow up and get a 9-5 job" type of thing.
  • 13. Borders are stressful, it doesn't matter how well prepared you are. Forget about the western standards, corruption does exist.
Crossing the border in Cambodia was quite an experience... check our post to see if it is as bad as people say
  • 14. If you are travelling with your couple, it is a matter of time you will want to kill each other a few times per day until you learn how to laugh about it.
  • 15. Travelling will verify, if it was your LIFE that really needed a change, or if it is YOU who was the problem. Get ready for some serious self-discovery moments and facing the real you.
  • 16. You will spend days stuck on never-ending bus rides or airports
  • 17. NO, NOT INTERESTED IN YOUR TUK-TUK OR TAXI, I had legs the last time I checked.
  • 18. You will lose your wallet, credit card or phone. Or they will get stolen. Both equally bad.
  • 19. One of the bad things about long-term travelling is that you will become obsessed with having a decent internet connection.
  • 20. MOSQUITOES EVERYWHERE.
  • 21. The number of homeless dogs on the streets will break your heart (and your girlfriend will want to adopt them all)
  • 22. People will only see the amazing bits about your travelling but no one realizes that you had to eat instant noodles for a week to recover your budget after losing a flight to Vietnam.
  • 23. Locals see you like a dollar machine, trying to squeeze every penny out of you. Bargaining will become your second nature to the point that you will question pricetags in every supermarket.
  • 24. You get tired of wearing the same clothes every day...
  • 25. ...and "how come we need a laundry again?"
  • 26. Your girlfriend takes WAY TOO MANY photos...
  • 27. ...and your boyfriend BARELY TRIES to pose for them.
  • 28. Then most surely you will lose half of them because your SD card will get damaged. Even if you are really tidy like us and save copies in the cloud, it will feel like a full-time job.
  • 29. You will get heartbroken at least a few times because of leaving amazing people and places behind.
  • 30. Last but not least, on our top 30 bad things about long-term travelling for us is - when you realise that it is coming to an end! So don't take it for granted and remind yourself every day how lucky you are.

The silver lining is that long-term travelling is so worth it. It makes you a better person: more open-minded, inspired and willing to take risks. It is the best life lesson you will ever get. When you will be 80 years old, you will not remember the 6 months you spent in the office, but the awesome times you had while travelling in South East Asia, South America, Africa or Europe.

Now that you know all the bad things about long-term travelling, if it didn’t kill your wanderlust- it means you are one of us!

Set free and explore the world!

 

Limited budget?

Make sure you check our 3 rules to travel cheap for authentic experience seekers​

item.content:encoded:
Few days before our one month visa in Vietnam expired, we decided to finish our north-to-south trip doing something special: we wanted to spend our last days Couchsurfing in Ho Chi Minh. This would give us the chance to spend some quality time with locals, something that we hadn’t managed so far for one reason or another.

This is how we found Thao, a girl who quitted her job to open Saigon English Adventures, an English school in Hoh Chi Minh, or better known as Saigon. She offers free accommodation at her place in exchange for volunteering in a few English classes with her students. We aren’t native speakers but we thought it should be good fun, so we applied. Thao promptly came back approving the stay. We were going to spend a few days interacting with Vietnamese people, exciting times!

She told us she would be away most of our stay as she was on holidays, so her roommate Jane would really be our host. We landed in Saigon from Da Nang at midnight, hopped into a Grab heading to the provided address. Jane picked us up with a huge smile and took us home. We would be sleeping in the living room, that turned out to be also the English school classroom!

 

Visiting Saigon

Next day we woke up early and went out to do some sightseeing. We walked to the city center (also called District 1) to discover a bit of Saigon, a unique city. Crazy traffic with motorbikes everywhere, chickens in the street, motorbike taxi drivers taking naps on their bikes, etc. A huge pink Catholic church caught our attention, as we had never seen one like it.

After walking a while we got to the War Memorial Museum. There we had another lesson of how sad and unnecessary wars are. For lunch, we got some cheap Pho, you can’t beat the price! (30 Vietnamese dongs = 1.5$).

From lunch to evening we wandered around the city center, where we found the strangest protest we have ever witnessed.

Next day we woke up early to visit the Cu Chi tunnels, one of the most popular attractions in Vietnam. If you want to read about this or you want to know how to visit the Cu Chi tunnels on our own, visit this post. Once back from the tunnels, the most exciting part of the trip was about to start: English classes!

 

English classes

Jane told us the English teacher couldn’t make it to the class, meaning we had to drive the class with her help. Iga got a bit stressed about it but I was fine with it, I knew it was going to be so much fun!

One by one, the students started arriving. They were more or less on our age, a bit younger maybe. And you can’t imagine how cute they were! Their English was limited but they could communicate, especially because they were not shy at all, which makes everything much easier. The class ended up being 2 hours of “Ask me anything” and it was just so much fun. We also got to know a bit about each of them and we can tell they are beautiful people.

After the class, they invited us for dinner at a very Vietnamese restaurant. They ordered so much traditional food, which we obviously appreciated as sometimes can be daunting to try new food in exotic countries. We drank, laughed, ate, exchanged social media profiles, life experiences…and that was it! At the end of the night we were so happy with the experience, and also a bit sad because we could not stay any longer with them.

Next day we woke up and met Thao, the Couchsurfing host and the director of the school. We got to chat a bit with her, enough to be inspired by the happiness she emits. After having breakfast, we assisted her with a new English class. This group’s level was very basic, plus you could tell they weren’t very used to be with foreign people, so they were a bit shy. Still, it was also a lot of fun.

Spending the weekend Couchsurfing in Ho Chi Minh was an amazing experience. It was exactly what we look for when traveling: visiting new places and meeting inspiring people, like Thao, Jane or their students. What about you? What do you look for when traveling?

item.content:encoded:
Going the Cu Chi tunnels on your own is something we recommend everyone to do when visiting Ho Chi Minh. The Cu Chi tunnels are an immense network of connecting underground tunnels that cover up to 250 km. Using these tunnels you could even get to Cambodia! They played a key role in the war to beat the Americans, who tried to destroy them many times but couldn’t.

To get there tourists usually hire a group tour but there is a way to get to the Cu Chi tunnels on your own. Most importantly, tours take tourists to a less authentic side of the tunnels, whereas going by yourself you get to the side where Vietnamese tourists go. Don’t worry, you will still get an English speaking guide. Ours was very funny!

How to get to the Cu Chi tunnels on your own

  1. Go to Pham Ngu Lao bus station.
  2. Take bus number 13 that will take you to Ben Xe Cu Chi (last stop).
  3. Get the bus 79 to Cu Chi tunnels.

Bus tickets are 7000 Vietnamese dongs each (0.3$), whereas tickets for the Cu Chi tunnels are 90000 dongs (4$). English speaking guide included in the price.

Funny fact: the buses don’t stop until the end of the journey, so it’s kind of a challenge to hop on/off the bus. I really felt bad for an old man trying to hop off, Vietnam is not a country for old men.

The visit

The visit shows how tough and driven the Vietnamese people were during the war. The tunnels are claustrophobic and crazy small. It’s incredible the Vietnamese managed to live for so long in a place like this. Everything was very well designed and thought of. They had hospitals, kitchens and leaders meeting rooms inside them. If one tunnel was bombed and compromised, the rest of the tunnels would be fine. And the list goes on and on.

Iga proved to be braver than me and entered in every single tunnel, while I only did it in a few. I’m going to make up an excuse and say I’m too tall (I’m not). There was one tunnel in which you could even hear a bat flying around haha. Nope, I’m not going in there sir!

At the end of the visit, you can shoot some guns if you’re into that (we aren’t). There is also a beautiful temple in honor of the war victims and Ho Chi Minh. We were lucky to see a school trip there, participating in a ceremony in Ho Chi Minh’s honor, singing and waving Vietnamese flag. Very patriotic, just like Vietnamese are!

If you liked it, share it!

item.title: Ha Long Bay or Sapa? What to choose

item.description:

Lucky you, we did both and here we are to help you out! Price When choosing between Ha Long Bay or Sapa you need to […]

The post Ha Long Bay or Sapa? What to choose appeared first on It feels good to be lost.
item.content:encoded:
Ha Long Bay or Sapa? This is probably the most asked question by visitors to the north of Vietnam. Breathtaking ricefields landscapes or thousand of islands surrounded by emerald waters? Lucky you, we did both and here we are to help you out!

Price

When choosing between Ha Long Bay or Sapa you need to keep in mind how much money you want to spend. For both options, there are so many companies and different packages, but in general, Ha Long Bay is a more expensive experience.

Sapa prices oscillate between 40$ to 75$ for a 1 night and 2 days trekking, including a homestay in a village. Group size goes from 2 to 6. For this price, you will only be able to do day-trips to Ha Long Bay. A 1 night and 2 days experience in Ha Long Bay will be around 80$ to 250$ depending on the cruise you choose.

What we picked: For Sapa, we chose Sapa O’Chau, since a friend highly recommended to us and they do sustainable employment for the people in the area, which is always a plus. We chose the tour called “Off the beaten track” as we don’t like touristic activities and we paid 60$ each. The price didn’t include transportation. You can get there by train or bus, making the latter more affordable. We got a sleeper bus for a night ride and it was very comfortable (only 10$ per person).

Ha Long Bay is one of the “you get what you pay for” places. If you get a cheap one, you may end up in an awful boat with awful food, wishing the cruise finishes as soon as possible. Thus, we went really out of our budget and chose the package also called “Off the beaten track” offered by Indochina Junk for 149$ per person. Important to note that most of the cruises sleep in Ha Long Bay, along with thousands of boats. Choosing that package we wanted to avoid the crowds- our cruise spent the night on Bai Tu Long Bay with only a few boats on the horizon. The boat was pretty good. The price included a VERY comfortable transportation in a private van to Ha Long Bay, which takes around 4 hours from Hanoi.

Price: easy win for Sapa

 

Experience

I think when choosing between Ha Long Bay or Sapa you need to be very clear about your expectations and what are you looking for.

For us, Sapa is one of the highlights of all our trips. Our guide and homestay were simply incredible. We learned so much about her village and tribe, the landscape was breathtaking and the food was authentic. Most importantly, we didn’t see a single tourist for 2 days. When we left Sapa, we felt like leaving our second home, but we were full of joy thanks to Xuan, our guide. The connection you create with the place and people during these 2 days of trekking is amazing. We felt really inspired by Xuan and energized to travel! FYI, You need to be aware that Sapa is famous for being overcrowded by tourists so you have to be careful if you want a similar experience!

If you want to know more about our experience in Sapa, check out this post

Ha Long Bay is impressive. The boat was beautiful. The food was AMAZING. The activities are alright, but not breathtaking. A couple of hours kayaking and visiting a fisherman village. They also let us swim for 30 minutes in open water, which was nice. We missed being able to swim at some beach but this is forbidden by the government. Obviously, you have no independence as everything is planned.

On the plus side, the sunset was the most beautiful we’ve ever seen in our life.

Experience: Sapa wins by a little

 

Comfort

If you’re going to Sapa you’re ready to trek mountains, sleep in a maybe not very comfortable homestay, get muddy if it rains, etc. For Ha Long Bay, you literally feel like Paris Hilton and you don’t need to move a finger. Just relax and enjoy the cruise with your Chihuahua!

Comfort: very easy win for Ha Long Bay

 

Just tell me already…Ha Long Bay or Sapa?

If you have the time and the budget, do BOTH. Especially because both experiences are unique and are so different from each other. However, If we had to choose only one, we would choose Sapa, just because we had a really authentic experience, one of those that makes travelling so rewarding.

What would you choose? Have you already been to any of the two? We would love to hear about your experience!

If you enjoyed the post, share it!

item.content:encoded:
Have you heard of the famous Shibuya crossing in Tokyo?

The Shibuya crossing in Tokyo is rumoured to be the busiest intersection in the world. With more than 3000 people crossing it at peak times and coming from all directions at once, this place is any photographer’s dream. This is why it has become one of the most popular sightseeing attractions in Tokyo, especially at night, when the flashing lights make it simply special.

The Shibuya crossing in Tokyo has appeared in many movies, such as Lost in Translation, The Fast and the Furious or Resident Evil.

A Japanese friend told me once that if you go to Tokyo and don’t cross it at least a few times you can’t really say you’ve been to Tokyo. I have to admit it looks hectic from outside, but from inside it feels really natural. It’s just one of many examples of how polite and organised is the Japanese culture and its people.

Everyone, including you, is waiting patiently for the green light. Once you step your foot down the zebra and follow the immense crowd, you realise that you participate in a live metaphor of the city- bursting with life and so crowded yet full of harmony and politeness. Thousands of people crossing in all directions within a few minutes and yet no one will bump into each other! Simply Zen.

We were a bit unlucky and spent a few very rainy days in Tokyo. With not much to do, we decided to come back to enjoy the rainy view from a Starbucks coffee on the second floor of a surrounding building. The sea of yellow umbrellas was just so cool.

What about you? Have you been at the Shibuya crossing in Tokyo? We would love to know your thoughts!

item.content:encoded:
There is this false belief, that you must be rich in order to travel. When explaining to some acquaintances how long we were gonna travel for, some of them would react like “Wow, you guys are loaded!“. We are far from being loaded! The funny thing is, those who say that probably go on holidays for 2 weeks, spending the same money than us in 2 months! That’s why we want to share our 3 rules to travel cheap!

We’ve discovered that spending more money usually doesn’t make your trip any better, in fact, if anything, it makes it less authentic.

“I only have 2 weeks of holidays per year. I an definitively staying in that 5 stars hotel, look at that bath tube!”

1. Choose your destination wisely

Let’s be honest, your holidays are going to depend a lot on the country you are at. It’s not the same to visit Myanmar than visiting Switzerland. Whenever you go somewhere expensive, be aware that there is a tradeoff…

  • Moving by taxi if you feel tired vs public transport, meaning you end up exhausted every day
  • Eating wherever you feel into vs. eating in McDonald’s because you can’t afford anything else (e.g. Hong Kong is famous for its super cheap Michelin Star restaurants!)
  • Boat to that magic cave + kayaking + cooking lesson + motorbike tour vs free walking tour around the city
  • You get the idea…

Thus, one of the most important rules to travel cheap is to choose countries that are considered cheap for your budget. This does not mean you can’t go to, let’s say Japan, for 3 weeks and still make it affordable like we did.  However, for the same money, you could spend 6 weeks in Thailand without counting every penny!

2. Accommodation

The next of our rules to travel cheap is to stay away from hotels. Hotels are usually expensive and they are not worth the money. Plus, who wants to stay in a room where you can’t really tell which country you are at? We like to have a local experience, which hotels don’t really give you. Our favourites alternatives:

Airbnb

We find Airbnb great, as you get to stay in truly local places and, in seconds, you feel like you belong there. Say hi to new neighbours, get a morning coffee in the local shop, warm baguettes from the bakery around the corner, and fresh fruits from the food market nearby. We love to cook from time to time, it is a DIY way to experiment with the local cuisine and try out some new recipes.

Hosts usually try to help you as much as possible to get a positive review, so it’s a win-win. Fair to be said, Airbnb is not super cheap and the hassle of checking in/out it’s usually not worth it for short stays (1-2 nights). We go for Airbnb when we want to stay for the medium-long term (4-5 days at least).

TIP: Many hosts offer you discounts for staying a week or a month. If you are thinking about staying 5-6 days, check how much would it be 7 days, as it may even be cheaper! Same thing with monthly stays.

Booking.com

We use any of these services for short stays. If you are going 2 days-1 night somewhere, you aren’t going to spend much time in your room. Thus, just get something cheap, well-located, clean and move on. You really don’t need that Smart TV, you have it at home!

TIP: Also, if possible, book your accommodation only a few days before arriving at your destination. Why? Hosts lose money when they have their place empty so they will be happy offering discounts. You may get up to 30-40% discount on the price! This also applies to Airbnb.

CouchSurfing

At the beginning of our trip, we were a bit worried about staying for free in someone’s home, but we have to admit we were wrong. If you find the right host, it’s an unbelieve experience. Keep in mind these people invite strangers to their home for free, so they do it because they enjoy it!

TIP: Offer something in exchange to truly enjoy your stay – you can cook some local cuisine from your country or speak some English to their kids, it will make the best travel story.

We couchsurfed in a Japanese house in Hiroshima’s countryside with a local family and ended up singing Karaoke while drinking Sake. What hotel is going to give you that? And FOR FREE!

TrustedHouseSitter

Probably our favourite.

With this platform, you go to someone’s home to take care of their pets while they are away – for free. You live in their home, meaning they are fully equipped and ready to have a very comfortable stay. Sometimes the houses are dream houses, you would not believe it.

Of course, you have to love animals, otherwise, this is not for you. You’ll be taking care of cats, dogs or pretty much anything they have at home. For us, this is far from being a problem, as we love animals and taking care of those 2 lovely brothers cats it’s the perfect excuse to travel to that paradise island.

Staying FOR FREE in Koh Samui (Thailand), chilling by the pool and playing with 2 lovely cats? Yeah, I’m in

Keep in mind you’re not on holidays, meaning you should spend quality time with the animals and make sure they don’t miss their owners too much.

3. Transport

The last of our rules to travel cheap is, of course, related to transport. Some tips:

  • Don’t buy flights that are out of your budget. If possible, change your itinerary so you can fly cheaper. Never buy a flight without tracking for a few days how the price oscillates. Setting a Skyscanner alarm for a flight or Kayak “buy” advice are usually very useful.
  • Whenever possible, take buses as they are way cheaper than planes.
  • Using a regular taxi in, let’s say Bangkok, it’s pretty challenging, and you’re very likely to get ripped off. Use Uber or Grab. These apps make it really easy and they remove the language barrier. Happy times.

To travel around Asia, services like 12go are pure gold, as sometimes it can be challenging to buy tickets in a foreign country. Check it out!

EXTRA TIP: Try to travel at night. We know sleeping on a bus or plane is not very comfortable, but you will save one night of accommodation. Plus, overnight trains are so romantic! If planning to visit Thailand, make sure to take a sleeper train on the classic route Bangkok – Chiang Mai. We loved it.

Ok, these are our rules to travel cheap. However, we want to give you an extra piece of advice…

4. Activities (for free)!

Instead of splashing some cash on an expensive tour with a guide, do a quick search – chances are, there are some free city tours whenever you are!

One of the best experiences we have had so far in Vietnam was meeting Brian who showed us Hanoi on a free food tour (obviously the food was on us). He made us feel at home in a minute! By the way, that egg coffee was delicious!

What are your tricks to travel good and cheap? Please share with us!

If you liked it, please share it

item.content:encoded:
Why Koh Chang is the best island in Thailand?

Despite the competion being fierce, we do think there are strong arguments to believe that Koh Chang is the best island in Thailand. Koh Chang is part of a small archipielago of 3 islands: Koh Chang, Koh Mak and Koh Hut, located in Trat’s province, south-east of Thailand.

How to get there

Unfortunately there’s no airport in Koh Chang, making it a bit tricky to get there. Your options are:

  • Plane + taxi + ferry: Fly to Trat’s airport from Bangkok. Then take a taxi to the Ao Thammachat’s port, where you can reach Koh Chang by sea in 30 minutes. The boat price is 100 Bahts.
  • Bus + ferry: Departing from Ekkamai’s bug station in Bangkok, there are 2 buses (Transport Co. Ltd) departing at 07:45 and 9:00. The trip takes around 6 hours and you get a yummy snack. Then just take the boat.

Once you make it to Koh Chang, you can share a taxi with more people from the boat to make it to your hotel.

How to move around

Koh Chang is not a small island. From south to east it can easily take you one and a half hours. Your options to move around are:

  • Taxis: The price depends on where you’re going but keep in mind they’re generally pricey.
  • Renting a motorbike: The best and cheapest option if you know how to drive. Getting lost in Koh Chang driving a motorbike is one of our favourites memories from our trips around the world.

What to do

One of the things why Koh Chang is the best island in Thailand is, of course, the beaches. However, you should know Koh Chang is one of those places where you don’t really need to worry about what to do. Just ride a motorbike and GET LOST.

Klong Koi Beach

Paradise. The sand is amazing and the water is surprisingly warm. I could type here some fancy words trying to describe how good the beach is, but it wouldn’t make it justice, so just go and judge by youserlf. On your way, visit Bang Bao pier, where you can have a smoothie and do some shopping in the shops in the pier.

Lonely Beach

The beach in Lonely Beach is nothing special so you can avoid that. However, Lonely Beach is great to enjoy the food or have some drinks. The atmosphere is very chilled during the day, although in the night it can get a bit crazy as there are some parties going on.

Lonely beach is a great spot to enjoy sunrises. We enjoyed an awesome one in Warapura resort. They have happy hours going on in the early evening, which makes it the perfect spot to see the sunset. I wanna be back so bad!

White sand, Khlong Prao and Kai Bae beaches

You can visit all these in the same day. The first 2 are a bit touristic for our state (plus restaurants are definitely not cheap!) but in Kai Bae we had the beach for ourselves and we had a great time.

Kholong Phlu waterfall

If you get tired of beaches, you can go to Khlong Phlu, where you can have a nice short trek and enjoy the time sunbathing in a waterfall. You can dive in if you don’t mind the mind the company of the small-medium fishes!

All these spots are on the west side of the coast. We drove to the east side but it was definitely less worth it and we ended up turning our way around as there was pretty much nothing.

You can also go to Koh Mak and Koh Kut, the other islands. We’ve heard great things about them but they are a bit far so if you go, make sure you get some accommodation to spend the night and make the most of them.

Accomodation

Budget option: Little Eden Bungalows

Perfect for budget travelers. Located in Lonely Beach, there are about 10 small bungalows. I would recommend it for backpackers or couples looking to stay somewhere comfortable but authentic at the same time. They have a restaurant where the food is pretty good as well. They also rent motorbikes for a good price (300 bahts).

Comfort option: Santhiya Tree Koh Chang Resort

If you want to relax this is your place. Excellent location, amazing pool and in general great commodities. Live music, delicious breakfast, great sunsets, etc. An outstanding resort.
